NO ORCHESTRA HAS
BEEN SIGNED AS YET
Dance Is Part Of Plan To
Improve Social Life Of
Students
The Alumni Memorial Hall, commonly known as the Dorm, whose
name when mentioned brings to mind
a refuge for sleep, study, and eating,
will set aside books and slide rules
this Saturday, May 2, and assume a
different character in the occasion
of the inaugural Dorm Spring Dance.
This affair will cost $1.00 per couple,
and in order to suppress the largest
activity at Hopkins, that of going
stag, stag tickets will cost $1.50.
For this event the commodious
Commons Room, with its stained oak
panelling as a setting, will be appropriately decorated by a committee
headed by Bud Gusack. The dorm
cloak room will serve as check room
for the evening. The fact that this is
an enclosed room will avoid the "development into a Sarajevo" as was
witnessed at the recent Battle of Jazz.
A buffet table service is to be arranged for the dispensing of refreshments.
Many Tickets Already Sold
Bernie Pinck, chairman of the Dorm
Activities Committee, stated, "This
Dorm Spring Dance, although some.
thing new, is definitely destined to
be a success because of the great
number of tickets already sold and
the wonderful enthusiasm shown by
the entire campus." From the general attitude around the dorm, this
seems to be a true statement since
the affair is the only event which
has had the backing of the entire
dorm as a body. Besides, other dances
such as one tentatively planned by
the Barnstormers have been postponed
in favor of this affair.
Don Jeffers, approached for information as to whose orchestra was to
furnish music for the function said,
"I am sorry I am unable to tell you
what band will play as that will spoil
everything. I am now negotiating
with one band in New York and two
in Baltimore. Since everyone is swingcrazy, the band is to be of the swing
variety."
Dance Part Of New Plan
The Dorm Dance strikes a new
note in the attempt of the University
in cooperation with the residents to
make the dormitory more than just
a glorified boarding house. This plan
has already been placed in operation
with the commencement of work on
tennis courts and a baseball diamond
adjacent to the dormitory; and afterdinner speakers one night a week.
The committee in charge consists
of H. Weinberger, H. Steingrab, M.
Tuerk, B. Breiter, E. Cross, C. Rasin,
P. Perel, V. Giacinto, W. Grauer, B.
Pinck, D. Jeffers, and B. Gusack.

Marxian Discussion
GroupHearsMattern
Dr. Johannes Mattern, lecturer in
political science, will be the speaker
at the first meeting of the newly
organised Marxian Discussion in Levering Hall on Thursday, April 30, at
4:00 p. m. The new Club is sponsored
by a group of graduate and undergraduate students including Foster
Dowell, Walter Schlesinger, Stanley
Rappeport, Donald Emerson, Sidney
Levy, Russel Burkhart, Edgar Kernler, and Elijah Adams.
Believing that the theories of Karl
Marx have had considerable influence
upon the developments of the past
fifty years or more, the Club will hold
weekly meetings to discuss the origin
and growth of Marxist theory and to
analyse its political, economic, and
philosophical aspects.

Gilbert Chinard Chosen
Editor Of New Journal
Dr. Gilbert Chinard, Professor
of French and Comparative Literature at the Johns Hopkins University, has been chosen as one of
the editors of "The Franco-American Review," a quarterly journal
devoted to the cultural and historical relations of France and
America.
The "Review," which will be
launched in June, will be a cooperative effort on the part of a
group of prominent Americans and
Frenchmen. It will be bi-lingual,
articles by French authors appearing in French and those by Americans in English. While adequate
attention will be paid to current
topics, the chief purpose of the
editors will be to throw new light
upon the manifold historical aspects of Franco-American rela
tions.

Frosh, Sophs Hold
Peaceful Banquets
May 6 And 7 Set Aside For
Annual Class Affairs;
Plans Made Public
For the first, and perhaps the last,
time in many years the times and
places of the annual Sophomore and
Freshman Banquets are being made
public to all and sundry interested
because of the cessation of Hell Week
activities for this year.
The Freshman Banquet is to be
held on Wednesday evening, May 6,
in the Merchant's Club, where the
Sophomore Banquet will probably be
held on the following day, T'hursday.
Committees for both classes headed
by a joint committee composed of
Lex Sklenar, chairman, Tom Ellis,
and Bernie Vincenti have been meeting
during the past weeks and arranging
all the details.
Make Accommodations Early
According to James Lyle, chairman
of the Sophomore committee, the
tickets have been printed and are on
sale for $1.00 to class members who
have paid dues and for $1.35 to those
who have neglected to do so. Tickets
may be obtained from Lyle, Milton
Saul, Monroe Sarezky, and Stanley
Finkel. Mr. Lyle said, "Last year,
because everyone made reservations at
the last minute, several people could
not be accommodated. To avoid a
repetition of this arrangements must
be made early this year."
Arthur O'Keefe, chairman of the
F reshman committee, announced
prices of $1.00 and $1.50, the latter
price being for those who have not
yet paid dues. Tickets may be obtained from the class officers, Bob
Ward, Harry Hopkins, Cy Treib,
James Blucher, John McCarthy, and
James Harrington, and the committee
chairman.
Hell Week has been a tradition at
the Hopkins for many years and was
abandoned this year because of the
unfavorable publicity the University
might receive from outside sources
upon some of the "escapades" which
usually take place.

OBITUARY

Seniors Elect Pieper
And Bradford To Council

James Bradford and Ernest ,Pieper
were elected as Senior representatives
to the Student Council for the coming year, Mead Johnson, president of
the body, announced.
Johnson issued the rollowing statement: "During the election certain
infractions were committed, and the
offenders were apprehended. However, since such infractions did not in
any way offset the results, the election was allowed to stand."

Because of the interest aroused
among the students in the coming
Presidential elections, the NEWSLETTER will sponsor a straw vote
ballot to be taken next Wednesday. Ballot boxes will be distributed at strategic points throughout the school.

Why is the demand for Goodman so
great? Because he has gotten men
together to form his band who are
all real musicians. Any of them could
step with ease and facility from "Chistopher Columbus" to Beethoven's
Fifth. Because Goodman himself is

The band plays with a "tightness"

unapproached by any band today. It
achieves a blending of the low-down
basic rhythm and the sophisticated
interweaving of instruments with such
extreme ease that it appears almost
simple in execution.
Realizing that improvisation is the

himself with great soloists. Arthur
Rollini on the tenor sax, Jess Stacey
at the ivories and Gene Krupa, percussionist extraordinaire, are hard
men to lick in their fields.

Zucker, Harmel, Silver, Snyder To
Compete For Adams Prize
At Assembly
The finals of the annual declamation contest for the Adams Gold
Medal Will take place tomorrow at an
assembly to be held in the Lecture
Room of Latrobe Hall at 11:30. Four
members of the sophomore class—
Morris Zucker, Merel Harmel, Kenneth Silver, and William Snyder, with
Herschel Halbert as alternate, will
present selected speeches. Judges of
the contest are Prof. L. Wardlaw
Miles, Dr. Edward T. Norris, and Dr.
Walter Friedrich.
All four men are members of Dr.
Clifford Lyons's public speaking
class and gained places in the competition at the assembly after preliminary exercises last week in which
a dozen orators participated. Though
this assembly will not be compulsory,
members of the English Department
urged attendance. Every year competition for the Adams Prize is held
among second year men during the
third week in April.

At a luncheon held Monday at the
Southern Hotel, the organization of
the committees conducting the drive
was announced.
Undergrad Committee Meets
At a meeting of the Undergraduate
Committee Monday evening in the
Board of Trustees room in Remsen
Hall
twenty-seven
undergraduate
committeemen each received pledge
cards for personal solicitation. Each
member was assigned a group of prospects whom he will visit personally,
presenting the facts concerning the
University and asking for a contribution to the fund.
Committee Heads Named
Organization of the various committees to conduct the campaign was
announced Monday at a luncheon given at the Southern Hotel. The heads
of the committees were announced as
follows: Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of the University, chairman of
the general campaign committee;
Daniel Willard, president of the Board
of Trustees, chairman of the business
committee; Dr. Dean Lewis of the
Hopkins, chairman of the professional committee; Carlyle Barton, Baltimore lawyer and trustee of the University, chairman of the citizen's cornchairman of the women's committee;
mittee; Miss Mary C. Goodwillie,
the alumni committee, under which
J. Trueman Thompson, chairman of
separate groups from about fifty
classes of the University will operate;
Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, chairman of
the faculty committee; and Clarence
Weimer, chairman of the Undergraduate Committee. Four members of the
Undergraduate Committee ushered
at the luncheon. They were: C. Weimer, R. Levy, S. Voegle, and R. Clark.
In connection with the letters to
undergraduates sent out last week,
it was explained that pledges made
by means of the enclosed cards can
be deducted from the caution money.
"This is very important," explained
Stern, "for inasmuch as we are not
pressing the undergraduates for contributions, but would like to see a
good representation of student pledges
the contribution can be made easier
at this time of the year if it does not
involve the donation of cash."

Playshop Will Close
Year With Program
Entertainment At Cadoa Hall May
16 To Feature Two Plays
And Dance
As the concluding feature of the
1935-36 season, the Playshop of the
Johns Hopkins University has announced a program and dance to be
held at Cadoa Hall on May 16. Many
prominent figures will attend, and a
large and varied program is being
arranged for the evening. The program will feature two plays and will
be concluded with a dance from 11
until 1.
The two Saturday matinee performances of "Rip Van Winkle" have
been completely sold out, announced
Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin, director of the
Playshop. The regular performances
of the play were concluded last Saturday evening, each performance being greeted by a satisfied and satisfying audience.

In contrast to the disunified, al- facilities and hospitalization.
most individualistic Strike of 1935,
this year's speakers remained close
to the purpose of the strike. There was
no overlapping; each speaker approached the subject from some specific point of view. One attacked war
from a genetic and biological aspect,
as a weakener of the human race; two
subjected the causes of war to an objective, scientific analysis and arrived
at the conclusion that war was a
private,

profit-making

enterprise.

One attacked war as a murderer of
truth, a destroyer of that for which
the Hopkins exists.
There was, generally speaking, a
serious discussion of every phase of
war. The occasion, however, was not
without its

comic

interlude.

One

speaker seriously protested against
the Nye-Kvale Bill as an incursion
upon states' rights.
The strike was undoubtedly an improvement over those of 1934 and
1935 so far as the conduct of the
students is concerned. There are two
possible reasons for the improvement,
one or both of which may have been
decisive. Perhaps the undergraduate
body was actually interested in protesting against war or was interested
in granting complete freedom of
speech to those who were. Perhaps
they feared the effects of disorder
upon the University itself. We prefer
to feel that the first reason was the
real one, that it was the liberal
tradition which demanded tolerant,
sympathetic conduct.
Two hundred and fifty students
struck against war at the Hopkins.
Throughout the United States more
than half a million demonstrated as
part of a common cause. To what
avail? What effect can the strike
have on the policy of the American
government? As a point of information, it is worth noticing the percentage of increase in the number of
strikers. If the strikers increase next
year proportionately to the last two,
over one million students will participate in April. One million objectors
is nothing to be sneezed at. Coming
closer to home, what effect did it
have on the Hopkins campus? For
several days before and after the
strike, the entire campus was discussing war and its prevention. War
and war propaganda depend on people's not thinking about the matter.
Cosideration and analysis of the situation form, perhaps, the best safeguard against war itself.
And then, half a million men demanding peace—a number ever becoming larger—can put the fear of
God into any government.

... Troubles

The first two requests have been
granted; the second two, certainly
the more important, are open questions. It is generally agreed by the
Dormitory residents that the food itself isn't so •bad. In fact, it is fairly
well balanced—but it seems to lose
all its taste in the cooking. We cannot take it upon ourselves to suggest
any new principles in the culinary
art, beyond saying that a good cook
does not decrease, but rather increases
the taste of food. It is worth noting
as well the all-too-frequent cases of
ptomaine poisoning and other intestinal disorders which have become
fairly prevalent. It is true that in no
case could the trouble be traced definitely to the Dormitory kitchen, but
the coincidence is too close for comfort.
During the past three weeks, however, Dormitory residents have noted
a slight improvement in the quality
as well as the preparation of the food.
It has not yet been ascertained whether this is a permanent improvement
or merely a bid for next year's students. Judging from the comments
after last Wednesday's supper, the
plan of having after-dinner speakers
will aid considerably in bettering the
food.
The question of medical attention
and hospitalization is just as serious. In Baltimore, one of the world's
greatest medical centers, at the Johns
Hopkins University, perhaps the
world's greatest center of medical
knowledge—there is not adequate
provision for medical facilities. Rather paradoxical to be sure; but the fact
remains and it cannot be too much
emphasized.
The University furnishes students
with a list of physicians, most of
whom it seems, charge unusually high
fees—far more than the average student can afford. It seems strange that
some cooperative plan cannot be
worked out wich will guard more
carefully the health of the students of
the University—particularly those
whose homes are not in Baltimore,
since they find themselves in a completely unfamiliar environment when
they first reach the University.
The problem, however, is not only
that of Dormitory residents—but of
every student in the University. The
administration of the• Hopkins must
take action quickly. The question is
far more serious even, than it seems
at first glance. Undoubtedly, the majority of students of the University
would be willing to pay a small medical fee, if it assured them of. adequate medical attention in the case
of illness.

JUNE, JULY, AUGUST
The National Student Federation of
America, The International Study and
Hospitality Association of Geneva,and
The Open Road, international travel
agency, are combining their forces
and contacts to offer exceedingly unusual opportunities for American Students who wish to travel abroad this
summer.
The Open Road, which is the travel
group sponsoring these trips, is an
organization maintained in the interests of international friendship and
education. For over ten years this
club has served American students
who wish to widen their horizons by
acquaintance with peoples of other
countries.
There are several organized groups
planned for travel in Europe. One
trip consists of three or four day

visits in each of the following international cities: London, Copenhagen,
Stockholm, Helsingfors, Leningrad,
Moscow, Kiev, Warsaw, Berlin, Geneva, and Paris. The entire trip takes
nine and one-half weeks, and the
maximum cost is $600. This particular group is under the leadership of
Joseph Cadden, Secretary of the National Student Federation of America,
and editor of The National SZudent
Mirror.
Another group visits all of these
cities except Kiev, takes six weeks,
and costs about $550. This group is
under the leaderhip of George L. Collins of the University of Wisconsin
and leader in Cooperative Movements.
The members of this group will concentrate on the study of the prominent
European Consumer's clubs.

Apropo of a fairly recent song
hit, we heard the following story the
other day:
It seems that an habitual beggar
was feeling very tired one day as
he set out to work, and he determined
to get his day's work done quickly.
So when a prosperous-looking man
neared him, the beggar asked,'Won't
you please give me $4.65?"
"Why," answered the astonished
gentleman, "that's all you make in
a whole day's work, isn't it?"
"Sure," the money-seeker replied,
"but I'm putting all my begs in one
ask-it:"
To which we might add the theme
son of the G-men (no, not the Gashmen)—"We're putting all our yeggs
In one casket."

FAIR WARNING—
Don't say we didn't tell you. Did
you know that you don't have to take
any quiz or exam which has been previously announced?
Believe it or not, strange as it
seems, mirabile dictu, etc., this is
technically true!
We envision a general strike if the
final exam questions appear difficult.
* * *
Annette appears to be in a new
frame (not of mind) but we'll leather
be. If you don't believe us, just look
on Hal Wolfson's bureau.
* * *
Life is feudal, said the Middle-Aged
serf as he dug his spade in the ground.
* * *
A series of commendable projects
have just been undertaken by the dormitories and these deserve the support and cooperation of the entire
campus.
This Saturday a dance which promises not to be dormant will be held in
the common room at nine o'clock. This
is the place where the first June Week
was held at Homewood.
Magnolias to Bernie Pinck et al for
their work.

NUTS TO YOU—
As we walked into a corner drug
store around our neighborhood we
noticed an advertisement over a box
of confections which read, "Have a
date with a nut for two cents." It cost
us much more than that when we had
one.

and his baseball team for their admirable record this season. Only in their
second year of existence, the Hopkins
nine have met several strong teams,
many of them necessitating trips; and
as we understand, in spite of a meager
budget they will finish the season with

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1936

Lacrosse Team
Trounces CCNY
At N.Y. 14-8
Tommy Dukehart Leads
Jays To Victory With
Three Tallies
SWINDELL INACTIVE
Many Reserves See Action
During Large Portion
Of Fray
The Johns Hopkins Lacrosse team
made another bid for the Intercollegiate title when it defeated the stick
wielders of the City College of New
York last Saturday at Lewisohn
Stadium. When the dust settled, the
final count was 14-8.
The play, fierce and forceful at
times, waS" carried repeatedly into the
Lavender scoring area, and it was only
the stubborn defensive work exhibited
by the home team that kept the Blue
Jays at bay. Most of the scoring was
done in the first half of the encounter,
with Hopkins tallying for eleven goals
while the Knickerbockers sent the ball
into the netting five times. The second
period saw a fighting City aggregation
opposing a Morrill Machine composed
mainly of reserves. The scoring in this
canto was even for both arrays, each
adding three goals to its total to conclude the fray.
Dukehart Leads Attack
Tommy Dukehart, at his out-home
position, led the Big Blue attack with
:ce goals. Dorsey Yearley and
„anamer Himes, at midfield attack and
center respectively, followed Dukehart
with two scores apiece. Jack Kaufman, Bucky White, Pete Bernheim,
Don Naylor, Bob Levi, Herb Siegel,
nd Johnny Beeler completed the Hop.:ins scoring with one goal each.
Flit Gottfried, at first attack for
managed to flick the ball into
,he Hopkins cords four times to take
,he scoring honors for the game
Swindell Out
Captain Pete Swindell, captain and
nucleus of the Hopkins defense, was
unable to play against the New Yorkers. His bad ankle is still a bit off
kilter. Johnny 'Ghinger took up Swindell's position at point, and made a
creditable showing.
Norm Melvin, Blue Jay scoring
threat, was unable to make the trip
due to injuries received in the Mt.
Washington game. Melvin is getting
over the effects of a cracked rib, and
will probably take the field this Saturday when the 'crossemen from Rutgers invade Homewood.

Lacrossemen Face
Rutgers Saturday
Captain Swindell In Shape
For Contest With Visiting Scarlet Ten
The Johns Hopkins lacrosse team
will face its first difficult test in the
Intercollegiate series when it crosses
sticks with the hickory handlers of
Rutgers this Saturday at the Homewood Stadium. Rutgers

has

been

characterized in the past as having
one of the most skillful tens north of
the Mason-Dixon Line. Their prestige
thus far has been carefully preserved
by victories over their Alumni C. C.
N. Y., and by last week's 7 to 7 tie
with the Army.

Dance Is Part Of Plan To

Students
The Alumni Memorial Hall, commonly known as the Dorm, whose
name when mentioned brings to mind
a refuge for sleep, study, and eating,
will set aside books and slide rules
this Saturday, May 2, and assume a
different character in the occasion
of the inaugural Dorm Spring Dance.
This affair will cost $1.00 per couple,
and in order to suppress the largest
activity at Hopkins, that of going
stag, stag tickets will cost $1.50.
For this event the commodious
Commons Room, with its stained oak
panelling as a setting, will be appropriately decorated by a committee
headed by Bud Gusack. The dorm
cloak room will serve as check room
for the evening. The fact that this is
an enclosed room will avoid the "development into a Sarajevo" as was
witnessed at the recent Battle of Jazz.
A buffet table service is to be arranged for the dispensing of refreshments.
Many Tickets Already Sold
Bernie Pinck, chairman of the Dorm
Activities Committee, stated, "This
Dorm Spring Dance, although some.
thing new, is definitely destined to
be a success because of the great
number of tickets already sold and
the wonderful enthusiasm shown by
the entire campus." From the general attitude around the dorm, this
seems to be a true statement since
the affair is the only event which
has had the backing of the entire
dorm as a body. Besides, other dances
such as one tentatively planned by
the Barnstormers have been postponed
in favor of this affair.
Don Jeffers, approached for information as to whose orchestra was to
furnish music for the function said,
"I am sorry I am unable to tell you
what band will play as that will spoil
everything. I am now negotiating
with one band in New York and two
in Baltimore. Since everyone is swingcrazy, the band is to be of the swing
variety."
Dance Part Of New Plan
The Dorm Dance strikes a new
note in the attempt of the University
in cooperation with the residents to
make the dormitory more than just
a glorified boarding house. This plan
has already been placed in operation
with the commencement of work on
tennis courts and a baseball diamond
adjacent to the dormitory; and afterdinner speakers one night a week.
The committee in charge consists
of H. Weinberger, H. Steingrab, M.
Tuerk, B. Breiter, E. Cross, C. Rasin,
P. Perel, V. Giacinto, W. Grauer, B.
Pinck, D. Jeffers, and B. Gusack.

GroupHearsMattern
Dr. Johannes Mattern, lecturer in
political science, will be the speaker
at the first meeting of the newly
organised Marxian Discussion in Levering Hall on Thursday, April 30, at
4:00 p. m. The new Club is sponsored
by a group of graduate and undergraduate students including Foster
Dowell, Walter Schlesinger, Stanley
Rappeport, Donald Emerson, Sidney
Levy, Russel Burkhart, Edgar Kernler, and Elijah Adams.
Believing that the theories of Karl
Marx have had considerable influence
upon the developments of the past
fifty years or more, the Club will hold
weekly meetings to discuss the origin
and growth of Marxist theory and to
analyse its political, economic, and
philosophical aspects.

Gilbert Chinard Chosen
Editor Of New Journal
Dr. Gilbert Chinard, Professor
of French and Comparative Literature at the Johns Hopkins University, has been chosen as one of
the editors of "The Franco-American Review," a quarterly journal
devoted to the cultural and historical relations of France and
America.
The "Review," which will be
launched in June, will be a cooperative effort on the part of a
group of prominent Americans and
Frenchmen. It will be bi-lingual,
articles by French authors appearing in French and those by Americans in English. While adequate
attention will be paid to current
topics, the chief purpose of the
editors will be to throw new light
upon the manifold historical aspects of Franco-American rela
tions.

Plans Made Public
For the first, and perhaps the last,
time in many years the times and
places of the annual Sophomore and
Freshman Banquets are being made
public to all and sundry interested
because of the cessation of Hell Week
activities for this year.
The Freshman Banquet is to be
held on Wednesday evening, May 6,
in the Merchant's Club, where the
Sophomore Banquet will probably be
held on the following day, T'hursday.
Committees for both classes headed
by a joint committee composed of
Lex Sklenar, chairman, Tom Ellis,
and Bernie Vincenti have been meeting
during the past weeks and arranging
all the details.
Make Accommodations Early
According to James Lyle, chairman
of the Sophomore committee, the
tickets have been printed and are on
sale for $1.00 to class members who
have paid dues and for $1.35 to those
who have neglected to do so. Tickets
may be obtained from Lyle, Milton
Saul, Monroe Sarezky, and Stanley
Finkel. Mr. Lyle said, "Last year,
because everyone made reservations at
the last minute, several people could
not be accommodated. To avoid a
repetition of this arrangements must
be made early this year."
Arthur O'Keefe, chairman of the
F reshman committee, announced
prices of $1.00 and $1.50, the latter
price being for those who have not
yet paid dues. Tickets may be obtained from the class officers, Bob
Ward, Harry Hopkins, Cy Treib,
James Blucher, John McCarthy, and
James Harrington, and the committee
chairman.
Hell Week has been a tradition at
the Hopkins for many years and was
abandoned this year because of the
unfavorable publicity the University
might receive from outside sources
upon some of the "escapades" which
usually take place.

The finals of the annual declamation contest for the Adams Gold
Medal Will take place tomorrow at an
assembly to be held in the Lecture
Room of Latrobe Hall at 11:30. Four
members of the sophomore class—
Morris Zucker, Merel Harmel, Kenneth Silver, and William Snyder, with
Herschel Halbert as alternate, will
present selected speeches. Judges of
the contest are Prof. L. Wardlaw
Miles, Dr. Edward T. Norris, and Dr.
Walter Friedrich.
All four men are members of Dr.
Clifford Lyons's public speaking
class and gained places in the competition at the assembly after preliminary exercises last week in which
a dozen orators participated. Though
this assembly will not be compulsory,
members of the English Department
urged attendance. Every year competition for the Adams Prize is held
among second year men during the
third week in April.

At a luncheon held Monday at the
Southern Hotel, the organization of
the committees conducting the drive
was announced.
Undergrad Committee Meets
At a meeting of the Undergraduate
Committee Monday evening in the
Board of Trustees room in Remsen
Hall
twenty-seven
undergraduate
committeemen each received pledge
cards for personal solicitation. Each
member was assigned a group of prospects whom he will visit personally,
presenting the facts concerning the
University and asking for a contribution to the fund.
Committee Heads Named
Organization of the various committees to conduct the campaign was
announced Monday at a luncheon given at the Southern Hotel. The heads
of the committees were announced as
follows: Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of the University, chairman of
the general campaign committee;
Daniel Willard, president of the Board
of Trustees, chairman of the business
committee; Dr. Dean Lewis of the
Hopkins, chairman of the professional committee; Carlyle Barton, Baltimore lawyer and trustee of the University, chairman of the citizen's cornchairman of the women's committee;
mittee; Miss Mary C. Goodwillie,
the alumni committee, under which
J. Trueman Thompson, chairman of
separate groups from about fifty
classes of the University will operate;
Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, chairman of
the faculty committee; and Clarence
Weimer, chairman of the Undergraduate Committee. Four members of the
Undergraduate Committee ushered
at the luncheon. They were: C. Weimer, R. Levy, S. Voegle, and R. Clark.
In connection with the letters to
undergraduates sent out last week,
it was explained that pledges made
by means of the enclosed cards can
be deducted from the caution money.
"This is very important," explained
Stern, "for inasmuch as we are not
pressing the undergraduates for contributions, but would like to see a
good representation of student pledges
the contribution can be made easier
at this time of the year if it does not
involve the donation of cash."

Playshop Will Close
Year With Program
Entertainment At Cadoa Hall May
16 To Feature Two Plays
And Dance
As the concluding feature of the
1935-36 season, the Playshop of the
Johns Hopkins University has announced a program and dance to be
held at Cadoa Hall on May 16. Many
prominent figures will attend, and a
large and varied program is being
arranged for the evening. The program will feature two plays and will
be concluded with a dance from 11
until 1.
The two Saturday matinee performances of "Rip Van Winkle" have
been completely sold out, announced
Dr. N. Bryllion Fagin, director of the
Playshop. The regular performances
of the play were concluded last Saturday evening, each performance being greeted by a satisfied and satisfying audience.

In contrast to the disunified, al- facilities and hospitalization.
most individualistic Strike of 1935,
this year's speakers remained close
to the purpose of the strike. There was
no overlapping; each speaker approached the subject from some specific point of view. One attacked war
from a genetic and biological aspect,
as a weakener of the human race; two
subjected the causes of war to an objective, scientific analysis and arrived
at the conclusion that war was a
private,

profit-making

enterprise.

One attacked war as a murderer of
truth, a destroyer of that for which
the Hopkins exists.
There was, generally speaking, a
serious discussion of every phase of
war. The occasion, however, was not
without its

comic

interlude.

One

speaker seriously protested against
the Nye-Kvale Bill as an incursion
upon states' rights.
The strike was undoubtedly an improvement over those of 1934 and
1935 so far as the conduct of the
students is concerned. There are two
possible reasons for the improvement,
one or both of which may have been
decisive. Perhaps the undergraduate
body was actually interested in protesting against war or was interested
in granting complete freedom of
speech to those who were. Perhaps
they feared the effects of disorder
upon the University itself. We prefer
to feel that the first reason was the
real one, that it was the liberal
tradition which demanded tolerant,
sympathetic conduct.
Two hundred and fifty students
struck against war at the Hopkins.
Throughout the United States more
than half a million demonstrated as
part of a common cause. To what
avail? What effect can the strike
have on the policy of the American
government? As a point of information, it is worth noticing the percentage of increase in the number of
strikers. If the strikers increase next
year proportionately to the last two,
over one million students will participate in April. One million objectors
is nothing to be sneezed at. Coming
closer to home, what effect did it
have on the Hopkins campus? For
several days before and after the
strike, the entire campus was discussing war and its prevention. War
and war propaganda depend on people's not thinking about the matter.
Cosideration and analysis of the situation form, perhaps, the best safeguard against war itself.
And then, half a million men demanding peace—a number ever becoming larger—can put the fear of
God into any government.

... Troubles

The first two requests have been
granted; the second two, certainly
the more important, are open questions. It is generally agreed by the
Dormitory residents that the food itself isn't so •bad. In fact, it is fairly
well balanced—but it seems to lose
all its taste in the cooking. We cannot take it upon ourselves to suggest
any new principles in the culinary
art, beyond saying that a good cook
does not decrease, but rather increases
the taste of food. It is worth noting
as well the all-too-frequent cases of
ptomaine poisoning and other intestinal disorders which have become
fairly prevalent. It is true that in no
case could the trouble be traced definitely to the Dormitory kitchen, but
the coincidence is too close for comfort.
During the past three weeks, however, Dormitory residents have noted
a slight improvement in the quality
as well as the preparation of the food.
It has not yet been ascertained whether this is a permanent improvement
or merely a bid for next year's students. Judging from the comments
after last Wednesday's supper, the
plan of having after-dinner speakers
will aid considerably in bettering the
food.
The question of medical attention
and hospitalization is just as serious. In Baltimore, one of the world's
greatest medical centers, at the Johns
Hopkins University, perhaps the
world's greatest center of medical
knowledge—there is not adequate
provision for medical facilities. Rather paradoxical to be sure; but the fact
remains and it cannot be too much
emphasized.
The University furnishes students
with a list of physicians, most of
whom it seems, charge unusually high
fees—far more than the average student can afford. It seems strange that
some cooperative plan cannot be
worked out wich will guard more
carefully the health of the students of
the University—particularly those
whose homes are not in Baltimore,
since they find themselves in a completely unfamiliar environment when
they first reach the University.
The problem, however, is not only
that of Dormitory residents—but of
every student in the University. The
administration of the• Hopkins must
take action quickly. The question is
far more serious even, than it seems
at first glance. Undoubtedly, the majority of students of the University
would be willing to pay a small medical fee, if it assured them of. adequate medical attention in the case
of illness.

JUNE, JULY, AUGUST
The National Student Federation of
America, The International Study and
Hospitality Association of Geneva,and
The Open Road, international travel
agency, are combining their forces
and contacts to offer exceedingly unusual opportunities for American Students who wish to travel abroad this
summer.
The Open Road, which is the travel
group sponsoring these trips, is an
organization maintained in the interests of international friendship and
education. For over ten years this
club has served American students
who wish to widen their horizons by
acquaintance with peoples of other
countries.
There are several organized groups
planned for travel in Europe. One
trip consists of three or four day

visits in each of the following international cities: London, Copenhagen,
Stockholm, Helsingfors, Leningrad,
Moscow, Kiev, Warsaw, Berlin, Geneva, and Paris. The entire trip takes
nine and one-half weeks, and the
maximum cost is $600. This particular group is under the leadership of
Joseph Cadden, Secretary of the National Student Federation of America,
and editor of The National SZudent
Mirror.
Another group visits all of these
cities except Kiev, takes six weeks,
and costs about $550. This group is
under the leaderhip of George L. Collins of the University of Wisconsin
and leader in Cooperative Movements.
The members of this group will concentrate on the study of the prominent
European Consumer's clubs.

Apropo of a fairly recent song
hit, we heard the following story the
other day:
It seems that an habitual beggar
was feeling very tired one day as
he set out to work, and he determined
to get his day's work done quickly.
So when a prosperous-looking man
neared him, the beggar asked,'Won't
you please give me $4.65?"
"Why," answered the astonished
gentleman, "that's all you make in
a whole day's work, isn't it?"
"Sure," the money-seeker replied,
"but I'm putting all my begs in one
ask-it:"
To which we might add the theme
son of the G-men (no, not the Gashmen)—"We're putting all our yeggs
In one casket."

Don't say we didn't tell you. Did
you know that you don't have to take
any quiz or exam which has been previously announced?
Believe it or not, strange as it
seems, mirabile dictu, etc., this is
technically true!
We envision a general strike if the
final exam questions appear difficult.

us much more than that when we had
one.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 29, 1936

Lacrosse Team
Trounces CCNY
At N.Y. 14-8
Tommy Dukehart Leads
Jays To Victory With
Three Tallies
SWINDELL INACTIVE
Many Reserves See Action
During Large Portion
Of Fray
The Johns Hopkins Lacrosse team
made another bid for the Intercollegiate title when it defeated the stick
wielders of the City College of New
York last Saturday at Lewisohn
Stadium. When the dust settled, the
final count was 14-8.
The play, fierce and forceful at
times, waS" carried repeatedly into the
Lavender scoring area, and it was only
the stubborn defensive work exhibited
by the home team that kept the Blue
Jays at bay. Most of the scoring was
done in the first half of the encounter,
with Hopkins tallying for eleven goals
while the Knickerbockers sent the ball
into the netting five times. The second
period saw a fighting City aggregation
opposing a Morrill Machine composed
mainly of reserves. The scoring in this
canto was even for both arrays, each
adding three goals to its total to conclude the fray.
Dukehart Leads Attack
Tommy Dukehart, at his out-home
position, led the Big Blue attack with
:ce goals. Dorsey Yearley and
„anamer Himes, at midfield attack and
center respectively, followed Dukehart
with two scores apiece. Jack Kaufman, Bucky White, Pete Bernheim,
Don Naylor, Bob Levi, Herb Siegel,
nd Johnny Beeler completed the Hop.:ins scoring with one goal each.
Flit Gottfried, at first attack for
managed to flick the ball into
,he Hopkins cords four times to take
,he scoring honors for the game
Swindell Out
Captain Pete Swindell, captain and
nucleus of the Hopkins defense, was
unable to play against the New Yorkers. His bad ankle is still a bit off
kilter. Johnny 'Ghinger took up Swindell's position at point, and made a
creditable showing.
Norm Melvin, Blue Jay scoring
threat, was unable to make the trip
due to injuries received in the Mt.

A speech in defense of the R. 0. T.
C. was made by Major Guild. He
pointed out that the army would,
least of all, desire war, for it would
have to fight. "But," he said, "some
factors seem to have been overlooked
by those who advocate disarmament
as a means of preventing war. There
has never been a time at which the
United States was thrown into war
because she was prepared. On the
contrary, at the one time when we

were prepared when war threatened,
in 1867, a mere note of disapproval to
France caused her to withdraw from
Mexico in a hurry, not even waiting
for Maximilian."
Mr. Shils, advocating the Oxford
pledge, discussed its history, meaning, and advantages, brought out the
point that those who take this pledge
will not be encouraging other countries to attack the United States, for
the pledge is just as rapidly gaining
ground in other countries as in America.

At the regular Wednesday luncheon
of the American League Against War
and Fascism, held last week, Johannes
Mattern, professor of political science,
spoke on "What Hitler Has Done, to
and for German Youth."
Dr. Mattern briefly discussed the
origin of the Nazi movement in Germany. He said, "After the Great War,
in 1918 came the Democratic Republic, technically the most perfect democracy the world has ever seen, with
proportional representation to such an
extent that it became a veritable invitation for more diversification. This
perfect democracy was burdened with
the consequences of a lost war—loss
of valuable source material in European and colonial territory—and of
foreign markets. The number of unemployed had reached a new height,
and the state was hard put to give
adequate relief.

The committee will send expeditions
into Mexico and South Sea Islands to
study primitive tribes and the causes
of suicides in these primitive societies.

The reaction to this state of affairs
came with the advent of National Socialism, which gathered in the resentful, demoralized and discouraged
from all sides. Its stated objective
was to put an end to the process of
disintegration, to enforce coordination
of intellectual, social, political and
religious groups, and lastly, to convert a shadowy, liberal democratic
citizenship into a flesh and blood,
National Socialist citizenship. of racially homogenous Germans."
Following the procedure of other experienced groups, National Socialism
has sought to gain control of the
Youth as a guarantee of the future of
Nazism. Hitler youth are recruited
from both sexes, beginning at the
age of ten. The Hitler youth groups
are made attractive to youth by giving
them all kinds of concessions appealing to youth such as free Saturdays
for Hitler youth activities, while nonmembers must go to school.
National Socialism has completely
replaced the Church in education. Education is state controlled, and policy
is one of conformity from the lower
to the higher schools. The prevailing
state insists on indoctrination, and enlightenment is replaced by education
for political purposes.
"It is apparent then," concluded Dr.
Mattern, "that the chief objective of
National Socialism is the creation of
a New Generation completely indoctrinated as a guarantee of the permanence of the system."

Vote On Resolutions
The resolutions voted upon were:
That we condemn our country's billion dollar war budget, the largest
peace time budget in her history, as
a step toward war.
That the United States ship no
arms, munitions, food, or other supplies to an aggressor nation.
That we support the Nye-Kvale bill
for optional R. 0. T. C.

the SANTA MARIA
Columbus' Flag Ship

That, realizing the practical impossibility of our country's being attacked, and condemning an aggressive
war, we refuse to support the Government of the United States in any
war it may undertake.
That a continuation committee be
set up to carry out any resolutions
that may be adopted at this strike
and to handle any other relevant
problems that may occur.
The first three of the resolutions
were passed with little comment from
the strikers. In the fourth one, the
voting was too close for a decision
and the resolution was tabled. The
last resolution was passed along with
a motion to have the duties of the
continuation committee assumed by
the strike committee.

Sigerist Shows Social Ills
Dr. Sigerist in his address showed
that social ills were a cause of war.
He said that if these ills were remedied and the social structure were
in this manner made firm, chances of
war would be greatly lessened.

The Rev. Mr. Hutchison discussed
at length the nature of war. He said
that pacifism in itself is of little importance and that most people would
fight if they thought that they had
something high enough and good
enough to fight for.. "In other words,"
he continued, "the whole problem
comes down to the nature of war. If
it is the defense of human rights as
was believed in 1914, then we must
accept it as a necessary evil. But if
it is not that but something entirely
different, then we can form a different conclusion."

The speaker said, "the same economic forces that drew us into a war
in 1914 are today drawing us into another war. War is simply a scramble
for profit, and a soldier is the gunman
hired to do the trader's dirty work."
He closed with the appeal, "Will we
be duped again?"
